title: Barcelona owe £84m for Philippe Coutinho - and £230m to other clubs in transfer fees

Barcelona owe £84m for the transfer of Philippe Coutinho - and a grand total of £230m to other clubs, according to reports from Spain.

The Catalan giants signed Philippe Coutinho from the Anfield club back in 2018, splashing out £142million on the Brazilian, with a view to him replacing Andres Iniesta in midfield.

A large amount of this was paid up front, with Liverpool boss Jurgen Klopp reinvesting the money immediately in the likes of £75m centre-back Virgil van Dijk and £66m goalkeeper Alisson.

The rest of the money will be paid to the Reds in bonuses, with installments being triggered following certain milestones being hit.

(Image: Leicester City FC via Getty Imag)

According to Spanish publication AS, Barcelona still owe £84m for Coutinho.

It is not clear whether this amount is all related to bonuses, but £24m is said to be due in the short term, with £60m set to be paid in the future.

However, Barcelona club accounts state that the majority of this money is payable to a third party lender, with Liverpool set to receive just £4.5m.

It's not just Liverpool who are waiting on payments, with Barcelona reportedly owing clubs a total of £230m in transfer fees.

(Image: PHILIPP GUELLAND/EPA-EFE/REX)

The purchase of Coutinho back-fired immensely on Barcelona, with the Brazilian failing to cement himself a place in the first team.

Much speculation surrounded him in the summer and he was eventually sent out on loan to Bayern Munich, where he has rediscovered his form somewhat.
